title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide the correct choice and a valid justification equivalent to the following.

· 350 nm MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E9F@ . Photons with a wavelength of 350 nm MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E9F@ have a higher frequency than those with a wavelength of 440 nm MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E9F@ because frequency and wavelength are inversely proportional (ν= c λ ) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3FBD@ . Since frequency and energy are directly proportional (E=hν) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3EC9@ , the higher frequency (shorter wavelength) photons have the higher energy.

The response provides an explanation equivalent to the following.

· 350 nm MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E9F@ . Photons with a wavelength of 350 nm MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E9F@ have a higher frequency than those with a wavelength of 440 nm MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E9F@ because frequency and wavelength are inversely proportional (ν= c λ ) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3FBD@ . Since frequency and energy are directly proportional (E=hν) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3EC9@ , the higher frequency (shorter wavelength) photons have the higher energy.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide both the correct choice and a valid justification equivalent to the following.

· Endothermic. The diagram shows that the absorbance, and therefore the concentration, of BPB MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGcbGaaeiuaiaabkeaaaa@3B58@ is greater at high temperature. The increased concentration of products at elevated temperature is consistent with an endothermic reaction, according to Le Châtelier’s principle.

The response provides the correct choice and a valid justification equivalent to the following.

· Endothermic. The diagram shows that the absorbance, and therefore the concentration, of BPB MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGcbGaaeiuaiaabkeaaaa@3B58@ is greater at high temperature. The increased concentration of products at elevated temperature is consistent with an endothermic reaction, according to Le Châtelier’s principle.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly describe the effect of the error.

· The estimated molarity of BPB MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGcbGaaeiuaiaabkeaaaa@3B58@ would be too low. The residual water in the cuvette would slightly dilute the solution. Because absorbance and concentration are directly proportional, the diluted solution would give a lower absorbance reading than the undiluted solution and thus lead to an estimated concentration of BPB MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGcbGaaeiuaiaabkeaaaa@3B58@ that is too low.

The response correctly describes the effect of the error.

· The estimated molarity of BPB MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGcbGaaeiuaiaabkeaaaa@3B58@ would be too low. The residual water in the cuvette would slightly dilute the solution. Because absorbance and concentration are directly proportional, the diluted solution would give a lower absorbance reading than the undiluted solution and thus lead to an estimated concentration of BPB MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGcbGaaeiuaiaabkeaaaa@3B58@ that is too low.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide a valid explanation equivalent to the following.

· When the concentration of OH − MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGpbGaaeisamaaCaaaleqabaGaeyOeI0caaaaa@3BB2@ increases, the collisions between reactant particles occur more frequently per unit of time. The greater frequency of collisions leads to an increased rate of product formation and correspondingly a shorter half-life of the reaction.

The response provides a valid explanation equivalent to the following.

· When the concentration of OH − MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGpbGaaeisamaaCaaaleqabaGaeyOeI0caaaaa@3BB2@ increases, the collisions between reactant particles occur more frequently per unit of time. The greater frequency of collisions leads to an increased rate of product formation and correspondingly a shorter half-life of the reaction.

title: Part I
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide both the correct choice and a valid justification equivalent to one of the following.

· The magnitude of Δ H rxn ∘ MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGuoGaamisam aaDaaaleaacaWGYbGaamiEaiaad6gaaKqaGhaacWaJ8UigI8gaaaaa @416C@ will remain the same. Δ H rxn ∘ MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGuoGaamisam aaDaaaleaacaWGYbGaamiEaiaad6gaaKqaGhaacWaJ8UigI8gaaaaa @416C@ is an intensive property, depending on both the enthalpy change and the number of moles reacted. Regardless of the number of moles that react, the ratio of the enthalpy change per mole will always be the same.

OR

· The magnitude of Δ H rxn ∘ MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGuoGaamisam aaDaaaleaacaWGYbGaamiEaiaad6gaaKqaGhaacWaJ8UigI8gaaaaa @416C@ will remain the same. Although the [OH − ] MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D7B@ is increased, the number of moles of each reactant that is consumed is the same, as OH − MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGpbGaaeisamaaCaaaleqabaGaeyOeI0caaaaa@3BB2@ is not the limiting reactant. Hence, the magnitude of the enthalpy change per mole would be the same.

· The magnitude of Δ H rxn ∘ MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGuoGaamisam aaDaaaleaacaWGYbGaamiEaiaad6gaaKqaGhaacWaJ8UigI8gaaaaa @416C@ will remain the same. Although the [OH − ] MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D7B@ is increased, the number of moles of each reactant that is consumed is the same, as OH − MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGpbGaaeisamaaCaaaleqabaGaeyOeI0caaaaa@3BB2@ is not the limiting reactant. title: Part J
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide a valid correction to the chemical quantities.

· To make 0.100 M NaOH(aq) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4518@ , the student needs to dissolve 4.00 g MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D56@ of NaOH MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGobGaaeyyaiaab+eacaqGibaaaa@3C4D@ ( 0.100 mol MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3FED@ ) in 1.00 L MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D38@ of solution.

OR

· To make a 0.100 M MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3EF3@ solution, the student needs to dissolve 0.400 g MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E09@ of NaOH MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGobGaaeyyaiaab+eacaqGibaaaa@3C4D@ ( 0.0100 mol MathType@MTEF@5@5@@409F@ ) in 100.0 mL MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3EDB@ of solution.

OR

· This procedure makes a 1.00 M MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E39@ solution, so the student needs to dilute it by a factor of 10.

The response provides a valid correction to the chemical quantities.

· To make 0.100 M NaOH(aq) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4518@ , the student needs to dissolve 4.00 g MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D56@ of NaOH MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGobGaaeyyaiaab+eacaqGibaaaa@3C4D@ ( 0.100 mol MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3FED@ ) in 1.00 L MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D38@ of solution.

OR

· To make a 0.100 M MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3EF3@ solution, the student needs to dissolve 0.400 g MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E09@ of NaOH MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGobGaaeyyaiaab+eacaqGibaaaa@3C4D@ ( 0.0100 mol MathType@MTEF@5@5@@409F@ ) in 100.0 mL MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3EDB@ of solution.
